narratives.question_text: If a requirement, did this course occur in proper sequence within the School's educational program?  If not, where should it occur?
comments: If students are interested in the tall building design, anytime is fine.
it was a requirement and it shouldnt be one

Since this class is an elective, a student is free to take it at different points during his/her program.For me it was a proper time to pass the course since Im planning to apply for the summer internship to the company dealing with the large-scale projects. This class provided me with a good background.
Yes - It's a good design elective whether you're in your 1st, 2nd, or 3rd year
Not a req, but very interesting and well coupled with Pro Practice.

narratives.question_text: Comment on the body of material presented and the content of the course: sequence, syllabus, and assignments.
comments: These were clear and easy to understand.
Professor Moon taught me a lot of practical strategies which are all helpful.
the course material was appropriate for the course and was taught in a clear and good sequence

The syllabus comprised a very comprehensive study of skyscrapers:1.Development of skyscrapers in the course of history.2.Development and types of structural systems.3.Types and function of mechanical systems4.Architectural aspects, various facade systems utilized in skyscraper design5.Then we were given an opportunity to apply all the learned knowledge in our own design proposal.I think that the content of the program was very inclusive and interesting.

Great Material, Great Lectures - Yet Poor Sequencing. The Schedule Just Seemed Like a Hodge Podge of Information That Was Clearly Not In Sequence....However, With a Better Organizational Structure...It Can Become a Solid Overall Elective
Great exporsure to a technical side of one building type we rarely deal with, yet many of us will go on to work on.

narratives.question_text: What were your expectations for this course and how well were they met?
comments: I expected to learn structural system of tall buildings as well as design as an architect.
The goal was learning basic system of tall buildings, and it was achieved.
i expected to learn about structure from tall buildings and i feel i walked away with a great basic understanding of that. My expectations were met and exceded.

My expectations of this course were basically to familiarize myself with the approach to design of skyscrapers.The fact that in addition to that I had almost a studio on skyscrapers with regular consultations was just wonderful and even more than I had expected.
Met Expectations
Above.

narratives.question_text: Comment on the value of this course to you.
comments: Design reviewers and guest speakers were all great and helpful. I learned a lot from this class.
i really enjoyed the course. It was a great addition to my courses here at yale and the work from the final presentation will make a great addition to my portfolio.

This course was a very conscious choice.I was going to apply for an internship in a big company dealing with large-scale projects, possibly skyscrapers.This class provided great background for starting to deal with big projects.Therefore, my experience in this class was extremely valuable.
High Value
I think it is one of the most valuable I've had...The exposure to core design alone will prove incredibly useful down the road.

narratives.question_text: Comment on the effectiveness of the teaching by the courses's instructor
comments: Professors critic was accurate and helpful.
the professor was great. he was always easily reached by office or email and I truly enjoyed learning from him

Id like to emphasize very high effectiveness of Professor Moons instruction. He has a high expertise in both structures and architectural design. Therefore,on consultations I was given valuable suggestions concerning equally architecture of my tower, its structure, as well as mechanical systems.This ability of our Professor to provide such a complex approach was very important to me.

Good - sometimes it was hard to understand professor Moon because of his accent. In addition, he did carry a bias towards diagrid structures because it was a new trend that related to his ongoing professional work....seomthing he openly admitted to me and my teammate on various occasions. Nevertheless, overall he was a good professor
Fine...no complaints.

narratives.question_text: Suggestions you may have for course improvements:
comments: I would like this course extended to two semesters with study of precedents and theory of skyscrapers in the first semester and the design development in the second.
Great class! I enjoyed it and I learned a lot. Thanks Professor Moon!

Two issues came up within the class that I think are noteworthyFirst is the issue of using the same design work for two different classes...which was apparent in this elective. Research and precedent study overlap between studios and electives seems to be common and effective at this school, but this elective made we wonder where the fine line is between permitted and problematic studio/design overlap. One elective classmate in particular whose main design project was a diagrid facade structure around the Bauhaus had a project in this elective that was a "tall version" of the same diagrid facade system. It felt unfair throughout the studio process, seeing as myteammate and I made a completely different design project for this elective. However, based on the comments from the professor during the final, I guess this team had some special approval to use the same design for two different classes.Finally, the issue of having friends on final reviews hurt this elective as well. Overall, the professor was able to bring in an amazing set of jury members whose main work is tall building design. However, he also brought in his old advisor from MIT, who was not the right fit for the class. The professor, John Fernandez, tried to accuse us of green-washing because we brought up the word sustainability without including any defined sustainable infrastructure within the tower, even though we tried to explain to him that the tower was sustainable simply because it was an ultra-dense community of spaces right next to the citys main rail station (running on the premise brought up by such individuals as UPenn Professor Witold Rybczynski and Author David Owen concerning true sustainability). However, no matter how many times we tried to explain this fact, he simply ignored what we were saying and kept making tangent statements about sustainability and architecture.
Invite internal guest critics to evaluate design as well as practicalities.
